The amount of lies told in this picture must number near the hundreds, and that's sales to David Mamet, "it's a tough racket." The movie adapted from the hard-hitting play is cynical, profane and sinisterly funny and known as sort of an acting showcase because of the stellar cast. It's become a little dated, but it's still worth watching. I know just about every line of dialog. Maybe I shouldn't admit that. Jack Lemmon's Shelley Levine is a tragic character for the ages played with every ounce of dramatic tension Lemmon could muster; it was one of his last great roles. Pacino's Ricky Roma is hilarious and often over-the-top Pacino-style. I love his scenes with Ed Harris, who as Moss is the sinister heart of the plot, and Pacino's silent moments are great like when he's listening to Levine tell his sale. Kevin Spacey is a perfect Williamson, absorber of much abuse. Pacino shreds him repeatedly. Alec Baldwin's scene early in the film is the thing most people remember. It's darkly hilarious. And I can't forget Alan Arkin, the innocuous guy caught in between. The way Moss reels him in is fascinating. Anyways, if you're not into Mamet you probably won't like it and may even be bored, but as for me it's one of my favorite flicks. "What's this toilet paper you're handing me?"

A distinctly cynical but witty drama, that pokes fun at the world of professional sales, and features one of the best ensemble casts of the nineties.

James Foley takes a step up from directing Madonna videos to craft this entertaining drama that will speak to anyone who's ever had to work a job they've hated. Set in the office of a Chicago-based real estate agent, the film follows its floundering employees who are given an ultimatum of closing a deal or losing their job. It's a testosterone fuelled marketplace which sees some employees charm their way to success and others plummet to new lows in order to avoid the chopping block. 

In terms of the cast, things really couldn't get better. Jack Lemmon leads the team with a sympathetic turn as down-on-his-luck Shelley Levene. Once the biggest man in the office, recent years have seen him fall to the bottom of the heap, overtaken by younger and more ruthless salesmen. His performance is one of the film's best, as Lemmon really captures the audience's sympathy with his desperate portrayal. Alongside him Alan Arkin and Ed Harris play less likeable but equally troubled salesmen, and both bring their A-game to the roles. Similarly Kevin Spacey stars as their inept office manager, while Alec Baldwin puts in a great supporting performance despite only appearing in one scene throughout the whole movie. His monologue here is one of the most memorable I think I've ever witnessed. British actor Jonathan Pryce also stars as an unsuspecting buyer, targeted by a slick salespitch made by Ricky Roma; the office's top dog. 

Played brilliantly by Al Pacino, the Roma character is a foul-mouthed hothead who knows how to make a sale. Pacino brings a huge amount of life to the role, standing out from the entire cast and showing once again just what a commanding screen presence he is. In 1993 Pacino received Oscar nominations for his work both here and in Scent of a Woman. Of course the Academy went for his baity role in the latter, but in terms of the better performance, I found his work here to be less contrived and simply more entertaining. This is a performance any who consider themselves a Pacino fan should see.

It should be noted that the film is quite dialogue heavy, and that may put some viewers off. However personally I feel the well-written albeit wordy screenplay acts as one of the film's strengths, filled with witty exchanges and providing great material for the talented cast to play with. That being said certain scenes have a tendency to drag, and though the film is generally well paced and by no means overstays its welcome at just 96 minutes, there are still one or two occasions where Foley could have tightened things up.

On the whole however, this is a very worthy drama featuring a host of fine performances, making it easily one of my favourite films of its year.

This is a great movie in particular respects. I think it should be required viewing for business-school freshmen. Its two great strengths are its writing and its acting. The screenplay by David Mamet is excellent, full of long angry monologues and venomous back and forth dialogue. The movie has little plot, but it's fascinating just to listen to the characters talk and insult each other. The movie has an unbelievably good cast, with some of the very best actors in the business at the time: Al Pacino, Jack Lemmon, Ed Harris, Kevin Spacey, Alan Arkin, and Alec Baldwin, and they all actually get adequate screen time and development. Only Pacino got an Oscar nomination when the movie was released, but I really think Lemmon and possibly Baldwin should have gotten nominations as well. It's particularly astonishing to see Lemmon throwing around curse words like it's nothing if you're acquainted with his nice-guy image from his 1950s and 1960s movies, but he does it just so well here; plus, his character goes through the most interesting transformations over the movie. Baldwin only has one scene at the beginning of the film, but it's an excellent scene; he's essentially playing the serious version of the funny character he now plays on 30 Rock, but he was just as convincing here as he is now on the show. Pacino gets some great showy monologue moments, the kind he's always been best with. Harris and Arkin have slightly smaller roles, but their conversations are really good while they last. This might be one of the best all-male ensemble casts I've ever seen. The movie's direction, by James Foley, is quite good, showing some visual flair without overdoing it. The only real flaw in the movie is the godawful soundtrack, which is cheesy jazz that does not fit the tone of the movie at all, sometimes is so loud as to nearly drown out the excellent dialogue, and seems to float in and out of the movie randomly. If ever there was a movie that had no need for a soundtrack, it was this one, and yet it got an absolutely terrible and obnoxious one. Other than the soundtrack, though, it's hard for me to find fault with this compelling multi-character-study.

A film that is drives, lives, and courses through your veins, David Mamet brings his stage play to the silver screen and discusses the world of the salesman. Mamet's words are so intricate and beautiful, filthy and philandering, and yet they sparkle with their brilliance. Most of the film contains these long, convoluted rants from different characters that contain subtle context about their livelihood. Their dialogue is full of the candor and realism of being a salesman in the cutthroat business of selling real estate. Mamet creates characters that are full of expectation, remorse, screaming at one another and anyone to let themselves finally become heard. These words come out of the mouths of a cast that is more impressively assembled than any ever before, including Al Pacino, Ed Harris, Alan Arkin, Jack Lemmon, Alec Baldwin, and Kevin Spacey. Each performance has its own breadth, no matter how unknown some of the actors were at the time (Kevin Spacey, I'm looking at you) and always feels desperate. Whether you're the iron willed pro who is closing in on the deal of the century or the warbling old man on his last leg against the crushing pain of unemployment and ruin, they each are wailing for someone to listen to their plight. Though these performances are amazing, it's Jack Lemmon who steals the show on more than one occasion as the chatterbox Shelley Levene. His rants are usually the longest, spiteful, most epithet filled pieces of Americana you have ever heard. He speaks on the state of salesman, his own problems, and time and again begs for understanding from his manager. Al Pacino is also impressive as the only closing salesman, pulling punches and scams in order to get to the yes. Everyone is always lying to their customers, but Pacino is suave and charismatic to boot. The film is set in 24 hours and doesn't move around many sets, but it encases many lives and the consequences of irrational behavior. A classic of American theater as well as film, this is one film that must be seen in your lifetime.

The production values are modest, there is not a whole lot going on, but the actors immediately immerse you in their slimy, underground world. This is an acting and screen writing clinic and it is not to be missed.

Ricky Roma: You never open your mouth until you know what the shot is. 

A thoroughly enjoyable film, despite the fact that very little actually happens. Much of the action is omitted, in favour of dialogue and re-telling of events. This dialogue however is sharp, snappy and witty, and the script as a whole is spot on. The all-star cast work well together, with each of the salesman making their marks on the film. Set almost interily in one or two rooms, and with a fairly basic plot, the film can be summarised as simple yet effective. Everything that is said has meaning, and every action, though few have consequences. Jack Lemmon in particular is enticing as an almost down-and-out salesman, and the twist involving his character at the end is unexpected. Overall very enjoyable, just dont expect much to happen.

A great ensemble of actors all giving their best, with fantastic script-work backing them up. The dialogue is fast, harsh and incredibly powerful and is arguably the strong point of the movie. Although, despite the plot seeming as if it wouldn't work dramatically with characters trying to make closures on estate sales, the motives of the characters and their stories (especially Lemmon's character's) of how they do their job is great to watch. Tension rises as the robbery is made, and the relationships between the men in the office shifts brilliantly as trust becomes an issue amongst them
